reviews.review_msg: Every time i left i felt like i had genuinely learned something that not only helped me develop my learning but could apply to my own life. It was really quite special. To be honest, there are a lot of readings but contrary to other classes the readings were genuinely interesting. Lectures are simply amazing and it was never boring or to hard.

(SA375) Probably the best prof I've ever had. Incredibly caring, focused on student wellbeing, knowledgeable, and funny. Participation is essential; no PowerPoints, always helpful and interesting discussions. Had to print readings for open-book exam, but she's willing to help out if cost is a problem. Absolutely would take this prof again.
Her lecture slides are pretty vague and the content (in my opinion) is hard to wrap your head around. There's so many articles. So many. All mandatory.
Dr.Millar was an exceptional professor, bringing interesting subjects and readings. I am exited to have her next term again
All around had a really good experience with her - she's very passionate about what she does and it's evident by her lectures.

she posts the textbooks pdf on canvas so you dont need to spend extra money on the class which is great but its followed often by 2 other readings (which she also puts on canvas) each week so its really heavy :( i actually liked how the midterm was weighted cos it saved me from the low grades i got on the papers

Great prof, LOTS of reading

There are multiple readings for every week of lecture. The midterm test is worth 40% of the final grade and requires a large amount of studying, TAs are awesome and clearly enjoy anthropology which helps. Recommend the course as an elective to learn more about the field.

It was an interesting introductory course. Each week had 3 readings assigned from different texts, thus was pretty heavy. I enjoyed this class but it bothered me how heavily weighted the midterm exam was, when we had 3 assignments and a final paper. Weighting an exam at 40% in an anthropology course seems counter-intuitive.
My experience with Kathleen was incredible! She is incredibly supportive of all of her students, and engages you with class content. One of my favourite professors in the sociology department by far.

Kathleen was a great prof! She tries to tie boring sociology theories into applicable situations in our modern day society. Make sure you email her or go to her office hours to get a better understanding of what she wants out of her assignments. Exams were fair - she even gave out a study guide! As long as you go to classes, you're set!

Kathleen is passionate about what she teaches. She loves group discussions and participation. I loved being in her seminars because it was the only class in my semester where I learned something applicable to real life and my program. Marking is fair. Easy to approach and to ask questions. Wished she put slides online more and had more powerpoints

Her lectures are interesting, but not much text. She loves to do discussions, so the only note taking chance is there. But she did change up her way of teaching at the end when she put up powerpoints of the main points, I liked that just so I know what I should be noting for. There is a refletion which you have to do weekly.

The feedback that Kathleen offers on writing assignments is incredibly helpful and challenges her students to become better writers. Lectures are very interesting and the seminar discussions are incredibly engaging. If you are truly interested in SOCANTH do not miss an opportunity to take a class with one of the best professors in the department!
